hov i&slong; þi&slong; &slong;eide þe king &punctelev; ȝweþur þe&slong; þef wene fiȝte

With &slong;courges and with &slong;taue&slong; &punctelev; fa&slong;te ȝe him bete
Þat he ne mouw iwielde neuere a lime &punctelev; are þat ȝe him lete
Ȝe seide vincent Vincent þov paiȝe&slong;t me wel &punctelev; þi wo&rrot;d ne þinchez me nouȝt ille
Ine fond neuere Man man þat so wel &punctelev; aco&rrot;dede to mi wille
¶Nov ich hopie to habbe game &punctelev; fo&rrot; ero&rrot;e me þouȝte longe
hit &slong;chal me tu&ydot;&rrot;ne to Io&ydot;e ioye and gleo &punctelev; and to þe pine&slong; &slong;tronge
Þe to&rrot;mento&rrot;e&slong; nomen þane holie Man man &punctelev; and to a piler him bounde

Þo heo ȝeuen him &slong;o&rrot;e&slong;t dunte&slong; &punctelev; leiȝen he gan wel smere
Þe to&rrot;mento&rrot;es &slong;eten adoun and cleopeden help &punctelev; þo heo werie were

Ȝwane heo weren werie of bete &punctelev; þe holi man bigan to &slong;peke

vincent Vincent &punctelev; al Atter atter is þi lo&rrot;e

ioie bigan to eo&rrot;ne &punctelev; þo he iheo&rrot;de þi&slong; dom
Þare nas non þat him miȝte ouertake &punctelev; are he to þe gibat com

vin⫽cent Vincent &punctelev; to dou&slong;te ib&rrot;end wereA large split in the parchment splits the writing between lines 68 and the bottom of the leaf. In most cases, the scribe has simple used the split as a word division, but the name "vincent" is split between the "n" and the "c". A double solidus follows the "n". It is here encoded as a punctuation character.

¶Þe Aungel aungel wa&slong; þar with him &punctelev; a&slong;e longe a&slong;e he þare wa&slong;
